contenedor1-P0: Travel on Chepe, one of the most impressive train rides in the world.
contenedor1-P1: Its 653 kilometer ride crosses Copper Canyon, a series of unique canyons of the type between Chihuahua and Sinaloa. Throughout the trip you will cross tunnels and bridges that are considered a jewel of mexican engineering, you will see as well one of the most majestic landscapes in Mexico.
contenedor1-P2: Venture in the mountains and get to know one of Mexico’s natural wonders aboard the Chihuahua-Pacífico train (Chepe).
contenedor1-P3: Walk in its forests, observe its vegetation, get to know historical sites and go deep in its towns, rich in culture and tradition.
contenedor1-P6: , ranging from 100 to 2,400 meters above sea level, characteristic that generates diverse microclimates.
Chex-P00: Live a unique experience all over incredible places throughout México aboard our trains.
Chex-P01: The train consists of 6 passenger cars, a bar car, a restaurant and a terrace, with a total capacity to transport 340 people.
Chex-P02: You will be able to enjoy the greatest commodities during your journey of more than 350 kilometers. On the way you can visit the terrace and the bar and get familiar with flavors of the region that restaurant Urike offers. You will also have the chance to get off at train stations El Fuerte, Divisadero and Creel.
Chex-P11: Let yourself be pampered with the comfort of the service of our executive class, with the coziest seats and panoramic windows that won’t allow you to miss a single detail of the majestic landscape of the Sierra Tarahumara.
Chex-P13: 48 ergonomic reclining seats with center table
Chex-P21: Excellent option to enjoy a comfortable and relaxing family trip with unforgettable views.
Chex-P28: Connect with your friends and/or family while enjoying a cocktail in a modern environment that includes all comforts.
Chex-P38: Enjoy the most incredible views and prepare your camera to take the best pictures while breathing the fresh air of the Sierra Tarahumara.
Chex-P46: Get to know the flavors of the sierra through seasonal dishes, in a two-level car in which you will not miss any details of the landscape thanks to its panoramic dome. Remember it’s of utter importance to reserve your place
Chre-P00: The train travels from beginning to end the imposing Sierra Tarahumara. This train only offers one class: Regional Tourist.
Chre-P01: Its 653-kilometer route dives in the Copper Canyon, a series of unique canyons of their type between Chihuahua and Sinaloa. Throughout the trip you will go through 86 tunnels and cross 37 bridges that are considered a jewel of Mexican engineering, in addition to seeing one of the grandest sceneries of Mexico.
Chre-P02: Chepe Regional’s ticket gives you the choice of descending at three different stations, with no additional cost. Wherever you decide to go down, you will be able to remain at least one night and take the train once again the next day. Every train consists of 4 to 7 wagons for 64 passengers, and a dining room with “à la Carte” menu (consumption is not included in the established fee).
Chre-P05: Tourist: In this service you will travel from Chihuahua to Los Mochis, or viceversa, passing through the stations Creel, Divisadero, Bahuichivo, and El Fuerte.
Chre-P07: We have food service throughout the complete tour.
Contacto-P08: Call us; it will be a pleasure to assist you.
Urike-P01: Conoce los sabores de la sierra a través de los platillos de temporada, en un carro de dos niveles en el que no te perderás ningún detalle del paisaje gracias a su domo panorámico.
Urike-P02: Recuerda que es importante reservar tu lugar.
Urike-P05: 6 Mesas cada una con capacidad para 4 comensales
Urike-P10: 6 Mesas cada una con capacidad para 4 comensales
Timesfares-P02: With your ticket you can descend on two stations with no extra cost. If you decide to go down you may remain one or more nights and board the train the next day.
Timesfares-P14: *It’s important that you arrive 30 minutes before your departure.
Timesfares-P19: We offer the option of descending at three different stations, with no extra cost. In the stations that you decide to get off you can stay at least one night and take the train the next day.
Timesfares-P31: *It’s important that you arrive at the station 30 minutes before your departure.
Destinations-P01: Let your adventurous spirit be your guide during the trip. There is so much to see, appreciate, enjoy and experience.
History-P03: the construction of the line that would unite Ojinaga with the Topolobampo Port begins.
History-P04: The complete connection lasts more than 100 years in getting built due the obstacles of the imposing Sierra Tarahumara.
History-P07: president Adolfo López Mateos inaugurated the Chihuahua Pacífico Railroad.
History-P10: when FERROMEX joins the National Rail System (Ferrocarriles Nacionales de México).
History-P13: the concession was granted to Ferrocarril Mexicano, S.A De C.V., beginning operations on February 19, 1998.

Bahuichivo-P00: 30 minutes from the Cerocahui Village, a Jesuit mission, established in the sixteenth century, is located
Bahuichivo-P01: on the edge of the Urique Canyon, and is a timber town par excellence.
Bahuichivo-P04: In its lookout you can enjoy one of the most impressive views of the Sierra
Bahuichivo-P05: Tarahumara: the Urique Canyon, and below it, the town of Urique, home of the famous Tarahumara marathon
Bahuichivo-P06: held every year. Impossible to miss out on these breathtaking landscapes.
Bahuichivo-P08: Working together with many organizations to improve
Bahuichivo-P09: the learning environment of Tarahumara children, this boarding school provides housing, food,
Bahuichivo-P10: and education to more than 300 Tarahumara girls from more than 45 communities in the area.
Bahuichivo-P12: “Huicochi”, meaning “place of many trees” in Tarahumara, is the ideal place to enjoy
Bahuichivo-P13: a walk starting on the banks of the river and finishing at the waterfall at the end of the canyon.
Bahuichivo-P14: The Jesuit Mission of San Francisco Church:
Bahuichivo-P15: The church, founded by Father Juan María de Salvatierra in 1964,
Bahuichivo-P16: is located in front of the townquare.
Divisadero-P01: Bordered by a series of lookouts and hanging bridges, it is considered a must place to visit due to the beauty
Divisadero-P02: of its landscapes, being that three of the most important canyons of the Sierra Tarahumara are located here:
Divisadero-P03: the Urique, Tararecua and Copper Canyon.
Divisadero-P05: Walks to the lookout, to the canyons and the Raramuris communities:
Divisadero-P07: can last from 3 to 6 hours, in which you can go down on foot until the bottom of the canyon,
Divisadero-P08: where Río Urique is located. You can also visit the houses of the Tarahumara and get to know their traditions and way of life, as well as continue
Divisadero-P10: Horse ride to the lookouts and bottom of the canyons.
Divisadero-P12: There is a route of 9 kilometers of special pathways to travel by mountain bike
Divisadero-P16: This park has a cableway with a length of 3 kilometers
Divisadero-P17: , a set of seven zip lines and 2 hanging bridges, with a length of 5 kilometers and a height of 450 meters,
Divisadero-P18: paths for walks, bike rides, horse rides, camping spots, and areas for rappelling and rock climbing.
Divisadero-P19: You can’t leave before getting on the zip line “Zip Rider”, with a length of 2,650 meters. There is also a
Divisadero-P20: restaurant with a glass terrace where you will be able to take spectacular pictures.
Divisadero-P25: Zip Rider (2,650 meter zip line, the longest one in the world).
Divisadero-P27: (birds, flora and fauna, sunrises, sunsets, and the stars)
Divisadero-P28: Visits to schools and Tarahumara communities
Chihuahua-P00: The capital of the biggest state of Mexico, modern and industrial city. Witness of many of the
Chihuahua-P01: biggest historical events of our country, from archeological remains to the development of events such as
Chihuahua-P02: the imprisonment and execution of Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla and the disruption of the Mexican Revolution.
Chihuahua-P05: Located in the center of the city, in front of the Plaza de Armas (Square of Arms) and City Hall.
Chihuahua-P06: It is considered the most important religious Baroque monument in the North of Mexico.
Chihuahua-P07: Muse de Arte Sacro (Museum of Sacred Art):
Chihuahua-P08: Located in the Cathedral’s basement. In its two permanent rooms
Chihuahua-P09: religious oil paintings dating from the 18th century are exhibited, as well as other types of religious objects such as the chair
Chihuahua-P10: that Pope John Paul ll used in 1990 during his visit to the city.
Chihuahua-P12: Originally a single floor enclosure that was employed for government offices,
Chihuahua-P13: , prison, public desk, and warehouse for selling corn and beans.
Chihuahua-P14: Currently, on the ground floor of the palace, you can find the Gallery of Arms and the Museum of Hidalgo,
Chihuahua-P15: built as a tribute to the father of the nation.
Chihuahua-P17: This estate, one of the most beautiful buildings in the city of Chihuahua, it was built
Chihuahua-P18: in 1910 by the orders of engineer Manuel Gameros, Chihuahuense miner, with an eclectic style and influence of
Chihuahua-P19: French architecture. However, when the Mexican Revolution burst, the family had to run away without having a chance of
Chihuahua-P21: In 1958 it became the Regional State Museum.
Chihuahua-P23: This was one of the homes and headquarters of General Francisco Villa, in which
Chihuahua-P24: he lived with his second wife.
Chihuahua-P25: It has personal belongings of the same Pancho Villa, photographs, weapons, documents related to
Chihuahua-P26: the Revolution, and the car in which he traveled when he was murdered in 1923.
Chihuahua-P28: This house was the home and residence of the president of the time: Don Benito Juarez,
Chihuahua-P30: It preserves the style of the period and has original documents signed by him, as well as a replica of
Chihuahua-P31: the carriage he used during his time at Chihuahua.
Chihuahua-P33: This place was the prison where Miguel Hidalgo and Allende were held, after having given
Chihuahua-P34: the cry of Dolores in 1810. It still preserves its dungeon and the stairway that led to it.
Creel-P00: Considered a “pueblo mágico” (magical town). Creel is the doorway to the Sierra Tarahumara and therefore, houses
Creel-P01: the largest population of Tarahumara, famous for being excellent runners, in addition to great artisans. Here,
Creel-P02: you can buy their famous crafts, such as baskets made with pine leaves, as well as figures carved in
Creel-P06: This place is located 10 minutes from Creel, which houses: Valle de los Hongos (Valley of the Fungi),
Creel-P07: Valle de las Ranas (Valley of the Frogs), Lake Arareko and Misión S. Ignacio (San Ignacio Mission). You can do the following activities:
Creel-P14: you can do the following activities:
Creel-P23: with a 30 m fall, surrounded by a beautiful pine and oak forest,
Creel-P24: and considered one of the most beautiful ones in the Sierra Tarahumara.
Creel-P26: Thermal waters that maintain a 35°C the entire year. Here you can appreciate
Creel-P27: the Tararecua Canyon. The visit lasts one day, and you can also camp.
Creel-P28: Piedra Volada (Flying Stone) Waterfall (2:45 hours from Creel):
Creel-P29: located in the Candameña Canyon, with a height of 453 m,
Creel-P30: this is the tallest waterfall in Mexico and the 11th tallest in the world. If you enjoy outdoor activities,
Creel-P31: you have a great opportunity here to practice hiking, exploration, camping, horseback riding and mountain biking.
Creel-P32: de montaña. You should consider a day trip.
Creel-P34: With 246 m of fall, this is the fifth largest waterfall in America.
Creel-P35: It has a 2 km path where you can descend to the bottom, and in the middle of the route, enjoy the
Creel-P36: view in its lookout La Ventana (The Window). You should consider a day trip.
Cuahutemoc-P00: This population in the state of Chihuahua grew in 1900 when the railroad arrived, but it grew
Cuahutemoc-P01: the most with the appearance of the Mennonites in 1921. The Mennonites are farmers with profoundly rooted religious traditions
Cuahutemoc-P02: descendants of Germans, and producers of the most famous and delicious cheese in Chihuahua.  Cuauhtémoc has the
Cuahutemoc-P03: biggest Mennonite community in the world and is the main producer of apples of the country, in addition of being
Cuahutemoc-P04: famous for their cheeses and creams that delight any palate.
Cuahutemoc-P05: In Mennonite colonies you can appreciate the ways and customs of approximately 48 thousand members of the community,
Cuahutemoc-P06: as well as try their delicious cheeses that have made them famous over the years.
Cuahutemoc-P09: : In 1956, the Santa Rosa de Lima de Cusihuiriachic Parish was built in Cuauhtémoc, which
Cuahutemoc-P10: was replaced in 1982 with the San Antonio de Padua Parish, which in 1955 was divided in three: Cristo Rey,
Cuahutemoc-P11: San Antonio and San Martín de Porres. A short time after, the San Antonio de Padua Parish became the new
Cuahutemoc-P14: This museum has 4 exhibition rooms, as well as
Cuahutemoc-P15: a broad audiovisual room, where you can appreciate, get to know, and value Mennonite customs and traditions.
Cuahutemoc-P16: It is located at km 10 of the Corredor Comercial Cuauhtémoc-Álvaro Obregón, where cooking and farming utensils are exhibited, as well as furniture brought by
Cuahutemoc-P19: The Mennonites arrived at Cuauhtémoc on March 8 1922; people of white skin, tall stature
Cuahutemoc-P20: and blue eyes. They used the railroad as a means of transportation to get there.
Cuahutemoc-P21: They began working the land planting corn, wheat and beans, but what favored most due to
Cuahutemoc-P22: climate was growing oats. Aside from agriculture, the Mennonites are known for having great ingenuity,
Cuahutemoc-P23: since they are such hard workers.
Cuahutemoc-P24: In Mennonite colonies you can appreciate the ways and customs of approximately 48 thousand members of the community,
Cuahutemoc-P25: as well as try their delicious cheeses that have made them famous over the years.
Fuerte-P00: The municipality of El Fuerte is located within the eco-touristic circuit of the Sea of Cortés. It possesses
Fuerte-P01: great natural, historical, architectural and cultural indigenous traditions.
Fuerte-P02: This municipality receives its name when, in 1610, the Spaniards built a fort to protect themselves
Fuerte-P03: from attacks of the local population. El Fuerte was an important mining center, where the wealth of the region
Fuerte-P04: can be seen in its old mansions, now converted into beautiful hotels, as well as the cathedral
Fuerte-P05: and the central square with lush vegetation.
Fuerte-P07: Walk along the boardwalk of the El Fuerte River and through the town.
Fuerte-P08: Kayak in the El Fuerte River
Fuerte-P09: Boat trip in the El Fuerte River.
Fuerte-P10: Assist talks about the El Fuerte River’s flora and fauna.
Fuerte-P12: Enjoy a meal with a view to the El Fuerte River.
Mochis-P00: Los Mochis is the third most important city of the state of Sinaloa, located in the municipality of Ahome
Mochis-P02: The city was founded in 1903, by American Benjamin Johnson, who established a cane plantation
Mochis-P04: Los Mochis has a population of 253,613. The term used to identify the city’s residents is “mochitense”.
Mochis-P05: Agricultural production is one of their main economic activities; their main crops include potatoes, corn,
Mochis-P06: wheat, beans, chickpeas, sugar cane, and cotton. Another important economic activity is fishing.
Mochis-P08: Bahía de Topolobampo (boat ride and fishing):
Mochis-P09: third biggest bay in the world, where you can go for a
Mochis-P10: boat ride to the dolphin sanctuary and visit the Island of Birds.You can also visit
Mochis-P11: the Bat Cave , Maviri Beach, and Farallón Island, a rocky island inhabited with seals and sea lions.
Mochis-P12: Here you can practice diving, snorkeling and fishing.
Mochis-P14: a botanic garden with one the most complete collections of cacti in the northwest of Mexico
Mochis-P15: and with more than 60 different bird species.
Mochis-P17: One of the best seafood restaurants of the area, with the typical essence
Mochis-P20: Seafood restaurant with an incredible view to the Bahía de Topolobampo.
Tac-P01: TERMS AND CONDITIONS PARA LOS SERVICIOS DE PASAJEROS EN LAS SIGUIENTES CLASES:
Tac-P03: The passenger accepts the following terms and conditions of the passenger service, the moment he/she acquires the ticket:
Tac-P05: The client can buy tickets through the Internet portal
Tac-P06: , as well as by sending an e-mail: chepe.reservaciones@ferromex.mx, or by telephone calling 018001 224373.
Tac-P07: For reserving and purchasing tickets the client must provide the following information:
Tac-P08: Complete name of the people that wish to travel;
Tac-P10: If you are a person with a disability, you must let us know.;
Tac-P12: Detailed schedule by dates and stations, and
Tac-P13: Specify which services you wish to reserve and/or buy: Tourist or Executive.
Tac-P14: For groups larger that 15 people, in case of making a reservation, the client will receive confirmation through an email informing the details of the reservation, as well as the method and payment deadline.
Tac-P15: The payment can be made through: direct purchase by credit card from the Internet portal and/or electronic transfer/bank deposit, when requested through email.
Tac-P16: At the moment you make the payment in the portal, you will receive your tickets.  In the case of an electronic transfer or bank deposit you will have to send the receipt of payment to the following email, along with the reservation’s confirmation number:
Tac-P17: chepe.reservaciones@ferromex.mx, once we have the corresponding payment you will receive your tickets via email. You must present the printed tickets to be able to board the train according to the purchased service.
Tac-P18: At the moment of making the payment, the Client accepts that the information detailed in the reservation’s confirmation is completely correct; therefore, in case of requesting any changes by accounts of the clients mistake, the client must pay the corresponding penalization detailed in point 12 of this document.
Tac-P19: In case the mistake was made on accounts of the railway, the modification will be made with no extra cost.
Tac-P21: The ticket is the official document for any clarification and covers your traveller’s insurance.
Tac-P22: The tickets are valid for trips up to 2 stops, with no extra cost, starting at the station of origin in the indicated date of the ticket.
Tac-P23: The price of the ticket only includes transportation aboard the train in a designated seat for the passenger, and his luggage no more than 3 pieces, which in total can’t exceed 50 kilograms.
Tac-P24: The ticket is personal and non-transferable. It can’t be resold and/or modified (the company reserves the right to demand the passenger’s ID).
Tac-P25: The price of the ticket includes the traveler’s insurance, which among others has the following coverage: medical expenses, funeral expenses, lost baggage and accidental death aboard the train and stations.
Tac-P26: Every passenger who boards the train must show his/her ticket, as well as an ID with his/her picture. Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe reserves the right to check the ticket before and during the journey
Tac-P28: The waiting room of the terminal stations of Chihuahua and Creel, in the state of Chihuaha and Los Mochis, Sinaloa, will open one hour before boarding, allowing passengers to enter even is the counter is closed.
Tac-P29: The passenger must be at the boarding station at least one hour before the departure of the corresponding train.
Tac-P30: At the moment of boarding, the passenger must show the ticket to the Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe staff, as well as an official ID with his/her picture.
Tac-P31: Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe assumes no obligation or responsibility for any change or delay, reasonably necessary or inevitable, prior to, or after the start of the provision of the contracted service, and the result of action, omission or any other fact, act, or unforeseen or unpredictable circumstance that is beyond the control of Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe.
Tac-P32: Climatic reasons, inconveniences produced by act of nature and/or any other fortuitous or unforeseen cause outside the control of Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe, may cause delays and/or unscheduled stops, which will not imply any type of obligation or liability on behalf of Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe.
Tac-P33: If the passenger, without a situation of imminent danger, for any reason, decides to descend the means of transport before his/her final destination indicated in the ticket, he will do so under his own risk and responsibility. On the other hand, Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe, to fulfill the service, requires providing another way of alternative transport and/or complementary transportation and the passenger decides for any cause or reason not to use such service and continue the trip by his/her own means, he/she will personally and exclusively assume the cost, risk and responsibility derived from such decision, without and liability for Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe.
Tac-P34: Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe, due to any incident of fortuitous cause or force majeure, contingency or previously mentioned situation, shall not be under any obligation to assume any liability towards the passenger or third parties due to delays or failure of making connections with other means of transport, or failing to comply with or adequately enjoy the obligations or rights, respectively, agreed with hotels, restaurants or commitments in general agreed with any person, entity or company, whichever their goal or corporate purpose.
Tac-P35: Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe reserves the right to provide the service without this implying the user’s rights of any claim, demand, payment or any other civil or commercial liability, if any of the following events occur:
Tac-P36: If there are weather conditions that prevent the execution of the trip and/or delay of it.
Tac-P37: If the passenger presents himself/herself under the influence of alcohol, and/or any toxic or prohibited substance.
Tac-P38: If the passenger carries guns, explosives, dangerous substances, illegal merchandise, or in general, any other element that constitutes a risk for the other passengers.
Tac-P39: If the passenger does not comply with the instructions of the Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe staff.
Tac-P40: If a ticket that doesn’t belong to the passenger is used, and/or the ticket was obtained through resale, or was previously modified.
Tac-P41: If the passenger does not prevent himself/herself in the indicated times to board with anticipation.
Tac-P42: Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe, reserves the right to substitute service wagons due to force majeure and for service or demand.
Tac-P44: At the moment of making your reservation and/or purchase, you will be assigned the seats of the segments you will travel. Seat designation is carried out in the order of reservation, ensuring that people who travel in groups can remain together.
Tac-P45: In the case that there aren’t enough seats, you should take the available ones.
Tac-P46: You cannot access one service to another when you have already started your trip. However, if you request any change within 30 days of your trip, the rules mentioned in point 12 of this document will be applied.
Tac-P48: Children younger than 18 must travel accompanied by a responsible adult.
Tac-P50: The ticket includes only 3 pieces that do not exceed 50 kilograms in total.
Tac-P51: It is not allowed to transport motorcycles, packages of large dimensions that can trouble other passengers, coolers, sacks, large bags or boxes, and packages in general. The passenger will have to use the services provided for such uses.
Tac-P52: Passengers with disabilities will be able to board with their assistance devices and required mobility for their transfer, such as wheelchairs, walkers, crutches, or any other device that they need. The passenger can also carry a reasonable amount of medicines and personal use items.
Tac-P53: It is recommended that the passenger does not include in his/her luggage valuable objects (money, jewels, etc.), fragile or delicate objects. Ferromex/Ferrocaril Chepe will not be responsible for losses or any broken object, and will not make any refunds.
Tac-P55: It is prohibited to board the train with food and/or drinks.
Tac-P56: It is not allowed to have bottles of wine or alcoholic drinks in sight, you can take them if they are closed and inside your luggage.
Tac-P58: No smoking is allowed on board the train, as well as at all stations on the route.
Tac-P60: It is allowed to travel aboard the train of passengers with any type of company dog, as long as they don’t represent a risk for the other passengers, and the owners assume responsibility of them at all times from the moment they purchase the ticket.
Tac-P61: 10. -PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, SICK PEOPLE, OR PREGNANT WOMEN
Tac-P62: They will not be able to travel:
Tac-P64: Women who are in state of gravidity after seven months of gestation;
Tac-P65: People who intend to travel alone who suffer from a disability and who medically need a caregiver;
Tac-P66: People who, due to the nature of their illness, present risks for other passengers, or whose transportation may imply a risk to their life due to the conditions of their health;
Tac-P67: People who are under the influence of narcotics or any psychotropic, unless they have, in the latter case, medical prescription, and;
Tac-P68: Las personas que porten armas sin el permiso respectivo, explosivos, sustancias peligrosas o en general, cualquier otro elemento que constituya un riesgo para los usuarios.
Tac-P69: In the express case, they must carry Medical Certificates. It will be mandatory to indicate at the time of reserving or making your purchase if:
Tac-P70: You need medical oxygen on board; in this case the medical certificate must indicate your need for oxygen and the level of flow you require per minute.  If you travel with your oxygen concentrator (only those authorized by the FAA).
Tac-P71: You have the need of travelling on a stretcher.
Tac-P72: You require transporting a baby or infant in an incubator
Tac-P73: You have an infection or contagious disease.
Tac-P74: You have a health problem that puts into reasonable doubt the conclusion of your trip with peace of mind, without the need for special medical assistance during the trip.
Tac-P75: Brain damage. It is required that the passenger travels with company.
Tac-P76: Coma state. Additional medical certificate will only be able to travel if accompanied by a family member or medic/nurse.
Tac-P77: End-stage disease or eviction due to different causes. In addition to the medical certificate, the passenger is required to travel with company.
Tac-P78: Epilepsy, the passenger is required to travel with company.
Tac-P79: Infectious disease. The passenger will not be allowed to travel is the disease is easily transmitted in closed environments.
Tac-P81: The staff of Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe makes a maximum effort to satisfy your travelling needs, at the same time taking into consideration the health and safety of the other passengers.
Tac-P82: Take into consideration that our staff is not authorized to help you eat, assist you in the toilet, meet physiological needs in your seat or provide medical services.
Tac-P83: Many disabilities are not entirely visible, which is why we depend on the information you provide, same information that will allow us to serve you based on your needs.
Tac-P84: With the intention of not bothering you by asking questions about your disability, we would like to know the services you may need to make your trip a pleasant one.
Tac-P86: The company may modify the rates without prior notice.
Tac-P87: Children under 3 years old do not pay a ticket and have no right to a seat.
Tac-P88: 12. - REQUEST FOR CHANGES, CANCELLATIONS OR REIMBURSEMENT BY THE PASSENGER
Tac-P89: All trains are subject to changes in schedule or route delays due to weather conditions or fortuitous events or force majeure, in which case the passenger cannot apply actions against the company. When one of these situations is presented, Ferromex/Ferrocarril Chepe will determine the movements of the train. The use of any portion of the ticket will mean the passenger’s acceptance of these terms and conditions.
Tac-P90: Every modification on behalf of the passenger to a sale causes a 10% charge.
Tac-P91: The purchased ticket cannot be canceled.
Tac-P92: Changes may be made if informed through the email chepe.reservaciones@ferromex.mx, with at least 30 days before the date of travel, and can be used during the following year from the date of the purchase, paying 10% over the total value to be able to travel with the new information.
Tac-P93: If the passenger or passengers cancel a segment of the trip there will be no reimbursement.
Tac-P94: The refund will proceed when the service is canceled due to fortuitous circumstances or force majeure attributable to the passenger and only 70% of the value of the ticket will be reimbursed.
Tac-P95: In these cases the passenger or passengers must send their scanned ticket, as well as a letter, requesting the refund, the information of their bank account and a telephone number. This should be sent to the email: chepe@ferromex.mx. The refund will be made in the following 15 business days and the deposit slip will be sent to the customer as proof of the transaction through email. With the refund request, the deposit slip and the copy of the ticket, a file will be opened for any clarification.
Tac-P96: 13. - CHANGES OR CANCELLATIONS ON BEHALF OF FERROMEX
Tac-P97: In the case that the passenger already has a purchased ticket and a fortuitous event or force majeure occurs, Ferromex undertakes to:
Tac-P99: In such event, the passenger may use the ticket to take the train in a contrary segment, having to pay the difference when it corresponds.
Tac-P100: In the cases considered appropriate and taking into consideration the passenger's safety, Ferromex will determine if it would be convenient to hire an external transportation service such as buses or authorized touring vans.
Tac-P101: In the cases in which the passengers are transferred by another means of transportation, according to the previous paragraph, in the segments that their ticket bought, this will not be reimbursed since the service will be taken as granted.
Tac-P102: Ferromex is not obliged to cover food or hotel expenses that result from a fortuitous event or force majeure not attributable to it.
Tac-P103: Ticket returns for events attributable to Ferromex will cause the refund of the amount corresponding to 100% of the segment that was not used, and only applies when the ticket issued by Ferrocarril Chepe is presented. The client will have thirty days to claim their refund or make use of it for the date that the passenger requires, not exceeding twelve months from the date of the occurring event.
Tac-P104: In these cases the refund will be deposited in the account that the passenger determines from 15 to 30 days after the request.
Tac-P106: The passenger may request the bill for the purchase of his/her ticket, sending the scanned copy of his ticket and his tax identification card, as well as his information in the body of the email, to the address cduran@ferromex.mx with copy to fescarcega@ferromex.mx. In three business days Ferromex will send the electronic bill through this same medium as of the date the mail is received. The request must be sent within the month you made your purchase; on the contrary, it cannot be subject to billing. The requested bills from day 1 to day 27 of the month will come out with the date of the current month, those requested from day 29 of the month will be made with the date of the following month.
Tac-P107: 15. - CONDITIONS OF THE RAILWAY TRANSPORTATION CONTRACT
Tac-P108: No agent, server, representative, carrier, or third party has the power or ability to modify, restrict or extend the terms of this document.
Comm-P02: The Tarahumara call themselves Rarámuri, meaning ‘runners on foot’ from the roots: rara (foot) and muri (to run)
Comm-P03: They live in the part of the Sierra Madre Occidental that crosses the state of Chihuahua and the southwest area of Durango and Sonora. The state of Chihuahua has 67 municipalities and the Raramuri are concentrated primarily in Guachochi, Norogachi, Bocoyna, Urique, Nonoava and San Francisco de Borja.
Comm-P04: The Tarahumara are known for their physical endurance and their running techniques, which have led them to take the top spots in ultramarathons.
Comm-P05: The Tarahumara live on ranches. Their homes are built from wood, adobe and stone. The most common is homes made from laying pine logs horizontally, which are joined at the corners, filling the cracks with mud.
Comm-P06: The traditional dress of the Tarahumara women is a design from colonial times: flowing pleated skirts or sipuchaka and loose-fitting blouses or mapachaka. The skirts and mapachaka are reversible. In their daily dress, women wear three or four skirts, and for celebrations, they add three more. Men wear shorts or wisiburka —with a longer point at the back—, with a woven sash and a loose-fitting shirt.
Comm-P07: Traditionally, women craft clay pots and pitchers; they also use palm to weave baskets of different sizes, while men make violins, bows and drums, and carve wood figures.
Comm-P08: Their language belongs to the Uto-Aztecan family and has various dialects. There are no aggressive words or hostile acts. There is a poetic nature to everything: “I greet you with the dove that chirps, I wish you health and happiness with your loved ones”. From childhood, they are respectful of the environment and the importance of preserving it.
Comm-P09: Farming corn is one of their main economic activities. Farming also plays a fundamental role in their social organization and many of their celebrations are closely related to the crop cycle.
Comm-P10: The Tarahumara gather for celebrations accompanied by music played on violins, drums and flutes.
Comm-P11: May your visit to the Sierra Tarahumara be an unforgettable experience!!!
